days.extended_instructions:
# The Internet, HTML, CSS and Bootstrap ## `20 min` Small presentation about the bootcamp, [click here to open it](https://docs.google.com/presentation/d/1--0xX43xyfngGTWVQEgmcbLuE7QCCz-jovL2JBOEPY0/edit#slide=id.g555ffcabca_1_0). ## `15 min` Play a game to get to know each other. - Everyone writes in an anonimus piece of paper with something about themselves. E.g: "I like dogs" or "I work on sales", etc. - Put all papers inside a cup and start the game. - Choose one student to start introducing himself: - First name and last. - What would you like to be called? - What do you do now? (for work) - What do you plan on doing when you become a developer? - Then, that student must pick one random paper from the cup and guess how is the person that wrote it. - After guessing, the person who wrote it must come next and introduce himself and pick another paper... etc. ## `5 min` Present the team Everyone introduces himself: Chief of Admissions, Chief of Career Support, Chief of Education, Main instructor, and teacher assistant. ## `15 min` Install the tools Start with Gitpod, invite all students, and make sure they are able to create workspaces and what the academy boilerplates are. ## `10 min` Go over prework concepts really fast Check if the students completed the prework, if ~70% of the students finished the prework you can continue with the rest of the class, otherwise you will have to postpone today's topics and today's focus only con starting/completing the prework projects and concepts with the students. ## If 70% of the students completed the prework you can continue with the rest of the day: ### How does the internet works? 1. The world is divided between servers and clients. 2. We call "clients" the computers with browsers or mobile apps. 3. We call servers where the centralized database is. ### HTTP Request vs Response** - The rules used for this client-sever communication is called HTTP, which stands for Hyper Text Transfer Protocol. - The way that you get the website is by sending a "Request" to the server. This tells the server what website or resource you are looking to view/use. The server then responds with the information. - The server then sends a response, which tells will confirm the receipt of the request and let your computer know that it will begin sending data. - This back and forth process will continue with more Request=>Response pairs until you have finished loading your remote resource. ### Everything is text! - With HTTP, it’s important to focus on the first T in the acronym, which stands for `Text`. In this protocol, everything is sent back and forth as TEXT. - While there are other protocols out there, for now, we want to remember that with HTTP – Everything is TEXT. - Make students open a picture with Notepad/TextEdit they will see the text that represents the image. ### Browser Interpretation - After your browser uses the HTTP protocol and receives the data as text, it then has the job of interpreting that text and converting it to the correct visual format. #### HTML - The first TEXT-based format we will see is HTML. - HTML its all about `` you open and close tags to give them basic format. - There are a lot of HTML tags but you only have to know a few and you can always google them. - Explain the basic tags like `

`,`

`,``,``, headings (`

`,`

`,etc). [[demo]] | :point_up: The most important thing to remember in HTML is to ALWAYS BE CLOSING! #### Always Be Closing and Indentation Matters** - Everything is going to be done in blocks of code. - First you open the block, then you close the block. ### CSS vs HTML ```css #id_selector { property: value; } .class_selector { property: value; } tag_selector { property: value; } ``` ## `20 min` Start the new content: Advanced CSS ### Specificity - Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity). - The class selector is the most used because it can be reused all over your website. - Show this [video that explains](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=In78mSOHmls) specificity to the class. - Combine selectors to get more specific about which element you are styling - Ask if anyone remembers what we said DRY Programming means? Don’t repeat yourself. You may think it’s funny that they call the opposite of DRY - WET programming, which they have given the following titles to: "write everything twice", "we enjoy typing" or "waste everyone's time"** ### Box Model - Box layout means that most elements can be thought of as boxes: with margin, padding, with and height. - There are 4 main parts to the typical box model: (draw the following on the board or show picture from breathcode) - Content: this is what is inside the box - Padding: this is spacing between the border and content (inside box also) - Border: this is the edge of the box - Margin: this is spacing between the outside of the box and the next element over in any direction. (which could be the edge of the page, another div, a paragraph, or even an image) - You can also have a background color or image, this will show in the content area of your box. #### The Display Property: - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline`: Display block its what makes an element behave like a box, inline elements have no margins. - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. - Display: flex; its the main tool for building complex layouts because it easily allows having several divs on the same line (columns). - I recommend going over the CSS and HTML [cheat sheets that we have available on the breathco.de platform under Assets](https://breatheco.de/assets/). ## Display Flex and how important it is. Take some time to explain display:flex and how it is used on today's project. #### The Position Property: - Position:fixed follows the user, it is mainly used for anoying modals or popups. - If one element has position:relative must always be companioned by one or more childs with position:absolute. Its broadly used for relating two elements to each other (one follows the other) - Compare `display:block` vs `display:inline-block`. ## `2:30 hr` Start the project! Read the instructions out loud with the class, make sure they understand. Students must start discussing on the whiteboard a strategy about the project. - From top to bottom identify the tags you will be using. - When to use `display:inline-block` and/or `position:absolute` or `position:relative`. - Setup the project with one `index.html` and one `styles.css` Answer questions individually with your teacher assistants.

days.label: Bootstrap

lessons.title: Bootstrap Tutorial: Learn Bootstrap 4 in 10 minutes

days.description: After a few years, developers started to re-use the same styles for most applications because you would always do the same classes (reusability), that is when Bootstrap was published by 2 ex-twitter employees.
key-concepts: bootstrap is just a stylesheet with useful classes
days.teacher_instructions: Explain Bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain: everything is a component from now on and you copy paste the necessary portions of HTML/CSS from the docs. There is a greed with rows and cols, its mobile first but responsive for 4 sizes.
days.extended_instructions:
## `20 min` Bootstrap

### What is bootstrap?

Just a predefined stylesheet inveted by [a guy at twitter (Mark Otto)](https://twitter.com/mdo?lang=en).

### Why?

- Because doing styles is repetitive, it was about time someone did a boilerplate.
- Its component oriented.
- It makes websites easier and faster to build.

### Bootstrap versions & download

Bootstrap has many versions, always check if you are using the last version of Bootstrap on your project, here you can find all the available versions: [https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/](https://getbootstrap.com/docs/versions/)

We recomend using a CDN to import bootstrap in your HTML like this one: [https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/](https://www.bootstrapcdn.com/)

### The Most Important (Used) Components

1. Navbar
2. Card
3. Modal: https://getbootstrap.com/docs/4.0/components/modal/#live-demo

### The Basic Workflow (asuming you have a wireframe or design)

1. Build your basic layout with the Grid (container, row and collumns)
1. Identify the components you will need (use piece of paper)
2. Copy & Paste the component code into your website.
3. Customize the component for your specific design.
4. Adjust anything else overriding with css styles on your own sylesheet.
5. Remember the utility classes to avoid doing to much custom CSS.

### Helper/Utility Classes that come with bootstrap*

These are classes you can attach that do things such as control margin or padding, control borders, or even float elements.
For example, if you wanted no margin on the left of the element, you can add the class ml-0 to the element and it will set the left margin to zero.

### Layout using Grid system

- Explain 12 column layout and how it works
- every line is a Row
- this row holds columns as immediate childs
- every Row on a page has 12 columns
- columns are equally measured in percentages so they are responsive.
- the basic sizes are: col, col-xs, col-sm, col-md, col-lg, col-xl

### Bootstrap does not have fonts or icons

We use google fonts and font awesome for that.

## `2:30min` Have class work on bootstrap instagram.

- Students gather in pairs tos strategize first (best practice)
- Read instructions out loud and have them build a strategy
- Have them identify the components.

Do not talk more, they will not be able to process it because they are overwhelmed, just help them code.

## `1:30min` Take some time the class explaining git in a general way

Git will be the first applicacion we will be using inside the command line, students must read about it and wat videos about it.

### What is git?

Git is an online, central code storage that allows developers to manage a code base in teams.

Some of the things you can do with git include:

1. You can collaborate on projects easily
2. see a history of revisions
3. Roll back to previous versions if a revision fails (version control)
4. Resolve code conflicts so that 2 developers don’t overwrite each other’s code.

Git is a necessity to any developer working today as it’s resolved many of the issues of working on a team or keeping version history on a project.

## For Next Class

Next class we will review GIT in more detail. If you haven’t already, please read the lesson on GIT in the breatheco.de platform.**Hello *World*!

days.extended_instructions:
# First time using Git

Last class you have introduced GitHub, students must have finish reading and watching videos and building their public profile with YML.

### About the GIT authentication:

The academy does not want to explain much about GIT SSH Authentication because it can be a cumbersome concept for now, we strongly recomend always using HTTP during the course and let students learn about SSH later.

### The Commit Object

Here is the lesson that talks about that: [https://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#commit-objects](https://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#commit-objects) 

Basically, a commit is a snapshot (picture) of what your project looked at during the moment of your commit. 

Commits represent a change in the current code, so if you don’t have any changes, you will receive a message saying there is nothing to commit.

There are four main parts in a commit:

1. Set of files which make up your snapshot at that time
2. Instructions pointing to the Parent commit objects
3. An SH1 (hash) name that serves as a unique identifier for that specific commit.
4. Commits also typically have comments, which should explain what was changed or addressed in the current commit

### The HEAD

The heads of the repository are like the "revision history of the project."  

A revision history is a list of commit objects that altogether contain all the changes that you and your other team members have made to the project files.

Every time you make a new commit, the head will move to that new commit.  (This way you are able to have access to the entire project history of commits.)

It is possible to move the head to a different commit, however, you must remember that commits made after the commit to which the head is pointing at are not possible to be reviewed.

### The Stage

When creating a commit, you select which files you wish to add to the commit. This is called "staging" your commit. (basically, preparing your formal commit object)

Typically, you will use "git add ." which adds all files to your stage for the current commit, then follow it with your commit.

### Branch

A branch allows you to work on a specific feature of code without compromising the main code in a repository.  [http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#a-head-object-is-a-list-of-commits](http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/how-to-use-git-version-control-system#a-head-object-is-a-list-of-commits) 

That means that each branch is a separate revision history.

The main branch of code in the repository is called "Master" typically

You can have as many different branches as you want in a repository/project.

Each branch has it’s own head which resides on the last commit of that branch. So if you have two branches, "Master" and “login”, each will have their own head on the last commit.

When you are satisfied with the feature you developed, you can merge it back in to master and it will bring all code changes, along with replace the head on master with the new head.

### Typical Flow

1. All new projects have to be initialized with git.  (git init)
    - This creates a git folder with all elements that define the git project.
    - At this point, it’s also good to set the remote for your project. This will tell the project what the address is for your repository so that you can push changes later.

 2. the command for this is:  git remote add origin https://github.com/user/repo.git 

 3. where the address at the end is your repository address or SSH address.

26. Whenever you have to stage your changes, you use "git add". As mentioned before, to add all file changes, “git add .” 

 > Note: conversely, you can condense this into the git commit by adding a flag "-a" which means add all files to the commit stage

4. Once you made changes to your code and you are ready to commit: You create a commit object by using "git commit -m ‘commit message’" or if you have not used git add, you can use the -a flag as mentioned before.

5. At this point, you want to use ‘git push’ to upload your changes

6. If you need to create a new branch:

    - git checkout -b [branch name]

    - next you need to switch to that branch to work on it

        3. git checkout [branch name]

    - when you complete your changes on a new branch, you merge the changes back in using the following:

        4. git merge [other branch name]


## Commit vs PUSH

We already discussed that a commit will allow you to create a new commit object. This is a local bundle you are preparing to upload.

When you finish your commit, you have to attempt to upload that code to the repository.

This is where git push comes in. It allows you to attempt to upload your changes to the repository.

If there are any issues where a conflict has arisen, you will have to resolve the conflicts before pushing your changes.

## Resolving Conflicts

For conflicts, git will notify you that there are issues.

- this typically occurs when two people are trying to modify the same file(s).

To proceed you need to:

- Get the new changes downloaded to your computer with ‘git pull’ or if you are on a branch, ‘git pull origin branch-name’

- Then you will be asked to merge the changes 

- Here you will have to edit the files with conflicts and resolve any changes. 

- Once you have resolved the conflicts, you can attempt to push changes again.

## Start Coding With The Students!

** At this point we will start the assignment for the git collaborative portfolio project.**

** Break the class into groups and assign a section of the portfolio project**

** [https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-collaborative-html-website/blob/master/website1/designs/guide.jpg]**(https://github.com/breatheco-de/exercise-collaborative-html-website/blob/master/website1/designs/guide.jpg)

* Use peer programming to complete the section quickly, then upload the changes to the repository your professor has provided.

Teacher will clone the repo in a new class repository and will handle updating the name of the template parts so that the site functions properly.

### Students Homework: 

Finish all pending projects including todays.

days.extended_instructions:
# Javascript Variables, DataTypes and Arrays

Start anwering any questions students may have.

## `20min` Javascript Intro:

**Warning**: Please do not explain the DOM or Events, also, don't explain loops or functions yet. Students will be overwhelmed.

### Why Javascript?

Static websites are just blog posts, but was about interactive applications like Instagram, Facebook, etc.?

Javascript lets us create dynamic HTML and CSS based on user or system interactions, for example:
- Adding an `li` to a `ul` when the user clicks on a button.
- Showing a banner or ad (publicity) based on the user IP address.
- Ask for information to a database.
- Write on a database using AJAX.
- etc.

Basically: Javascript its a programming language to generate HTML and CSS (text) based on events.

## The`<script>` tag:

All javascript must be done on a separate sheet (best practice).
You have to import to put that tag **right before the body closing tag**.
The code execution starts on the `window.onload = function(){}` like this:
```
//index.js

window.onload = function(){
    //your code here
}

//you can declar other functions here, but please don't write code outside functions
```

**Warning**: Carefull explaining the windown.onload, because today we are not suppose to overwhelme them with events and functions.

### Explain Variables:

Variables are javascript’s version of containers that hold some information.

An example of this is:

1. Let’s say we needed to store someone’s birthday for an age verification script
2. One of our variables might be: `var day = 29;`
3. There are three things going on here:
    - First, the computer interprets the letters VAR as the beginnig of a variable declaration.
    - After `VAR` it must always come the variable name: in our case is called `day`.
    - Secondly, we are storing a value of 29 in that variable.
    - Finally, notice the syntax. All javascript lines typically end with semicolon. There will be some cases where you don’t use semicolon and we will learn those later but for now, all lines are with semicolon.

3. Given that we defined the var above, `var day = 29;` if we want to display it for testing, we can show use the javascript console:
    - Explain how to open the google inspector console
    - So to display the variable, you would use: `console.log(day);`
    - will print on the console `29`

### Data Types

You can store 6 differnt types of values: Strings, Integers, Booleans, Arrays, Objects, Functions, Null and Undefined.

- Boolean - true/false
- String - always in quotes
- Number - any type of number -  integer numbers, negative numbers, decimal numbers, floats, etc.
- Undefined - nothing was set or specified for the variable. so the variable has no value
- Null - When a database or function returns nothing, it returns null
- Array - data sets [2,3,4,"cat",242,"d"]
- Object - You can explain objects like real life objects that are comprised by other datatypes, you can use the analogy with HTML Tags because the tags have properties taht describe them further. Objects behave the same way.

Note: Data Types on Breatheco.de: [http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-javascript-learn-to-code-in-javascript#data-types](http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-javascript-learn-to-code-in-javascript#data-types)

### String Contatenation

Suming two integers its not the same as suming two strings, as web developers we are going to be creating HTML using Javascript, we will contatenate like crazy!

### Arrays

Since we just learned what an array is, let’s look at some basic properties of an array:

1. value or item: The value stored on each position.
2. index or position: the position of the given value in the array `note: the first position starts at 0`
3. length - the total length of the array

Declaring an array [http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-an-array-define-array](http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/what-is-an-array-define-array#how-to-declare-an-array)

To initialize an array , you can use the following:
```js
let myArray = [];
```
This defines the array as an empty set so that you can add values later.

Note: Don’t use, use let or const.

You can also initialize an array with a value in it**
```js
let myArray = [1,2,3,4,5];
```
Displaying the value of an array using console, we can show it as `console.log(myArray[0]);`

Updating a specific position: `myArray[4]=3;`

Generating a random number using `Math.rand()`

## Javascript Exercises and Learnpack

Explain to the students how they learnpack exercises work:

There are 4 main exercises: Begin JS, Arrays, Functions, and Mastering Javascript, and they are supposed to be done in parallel because they share the same concepts E.g: You need to know about strings to know about functions because you probably will use a string within a function.

1. They can start any series of exercises by clicking on the gitpod button in GitHub (using the gitpod extensions)
2. Once the exercise engine is loaded and the exercises are running they can click "next" for each exercise.
3. If the engine is down the can type `learnpack start` to restart the engine.

They have to complete all exercises by the end of the Bootcamp and repeat some of them if possible, particularly the "arrays" exercises.

## Start Practicing

Open the begin js exercises and have the class take turns on the screen to complete each exercise during the class hours hours.

Note: You can stop the class anytime and explain a javascript concept if you see they need to re-enforce the concept.

days.extended_instructions:
## `20min` JS Review

- Start the class going over the same concepts of js again, make the class answer your questions about: 
- 1. What are variables?
- 2. What are data-types? 
- 3. What is the scope? 
- 4. What are functions?
- 5. What is the window.onload? Why do we use it?
- 6. What is a string and how to concatenate strings?
- 7. What is an HTML String? how can we generate HTML Strings as js devs.

## `2 hrs` First JS Project (Excuse Generator)

- Read the instructions with the students, and introduce the problem: How can we create a excuse? What are the pieces that we need to build?
- Students MUST discuss with each other how to approach the problem of creating an excuse, guide them.
- The project does not have to be fully finished at the end of the class, some students are slower than others, but at  least tgey should be half way and with a clear idea.
- To include the excuse into the document you can tell them tu use `document.querySelector('body').innerHTML = excuse;` but don't try to explain the DOM, that is for another class and they are already overwhelmed.

Explain to the students how they learnpack exercises work:

There are 4 main exercises: Begin JS, Arrays, Functions, and Mastering Javascript, and they are supposed to be done in parallel because they share the same concepts E.g: You need to know about strings to know about functions because you probably will use a string within a function.

1. They can start any series of exercises by clicking on the gitpod button in GitHub (using the gitpod extensions)
2. Once the exercise engine is loaded and the exercises are running they can click "next" for each exercise.
3. If the engine is down the can type `learnpack start` to restart the engine.

They have to complete all exercises by the end of the Bootcamp and repeat some of them if possible, particularly the "arrays" exercises.

## `30min` Continue Practicing and give homework

Open the function js exercises and have the class take turns on the screen to complete each exercise during the 3 hours.

Note: You can stop the class anytime and explain a javascript concept if you see they need to re-enforce the concept.

days.extended_instructions:
# Looping and Arrays

Welcome class.

## `1 min` Remind students the importance about finishing the JS exercises

Students should be completing those exercises HARD: Begin JS, Loops, Arrays, Functions and optionally Mastering JS.
Remind students that reading will do no help, this phase is about practice, practice and more practice.

## `5 min` Review last class

- We started generating HTML Strings for the first time, that is the developers ultimate goal.
- Data Types, Variables and Arrays.
- Algorithms run from top to bottom, line by line.
- You can skip lines with conditionals, repeat lines with loops and reuse lines with functions.
- Arrays have items (or values) and index (or position), they start at 0. And you can get the length with `myArray.length`.
- Concatenate stringgs using + and the new amazing type of quotes '`' that is easier for creating big dynamic strings.

## `10 min` Talk about looping: with and without arrays (for vs foreach).

- The main objective for a loop is to repeat a bunch of lines of code from the openin curly brace to the closing curly brace.
- There are several ways of looping but we will focus mainly in the `for` loop for now.
- Here is a 12min video explaining [all the different ways of looping](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=U3ZlQSOcOI0).
- You can add elements to an array with `push`.

## `10 min` Talk more in detail about functions

- Functions are the last thing to learn about basic algorithms (encouragement).
- You create a function when you find yourself doing the same thing all over.
- Functions purpose is to receive an input and return an output.
- The function stops executing after returning.
- Functions SHOULD USE VARIABLES declared ourside of them (best practice).
- Anonymus function vs normal function.
- In javascript, we will only use arrow functions (no the original type of function) because they are more similar to other programming languages functions.

## `2:20 min` hours Start coding with the students!

- Ask students to use the boilerplate for vanila.js.
- Read the instructions for the domain name generator and ask students to discuss and build the strategy on the whiteboard.

## ⚠ ️IMPORTANT `before leaving` Invite them to the coding weekend

This is the most important coding weekend of the entire course because they have to understand JS well to be able to continue learning more stuff.

# Practice Day (replits and projects)

## `5 min` Take any questions about javascript

Remind everyone that the all the replits about Javascript are extremelly important, the only way to become better is practicing.

## `10 min` Last review about JS (really fast)

- Everything starts on the window.onload
- A non declared variable value is `undefined` (this will help them read the console errors)
- If you forget to return, the function will return `undefined` (this will help them read the console errors)
- Our main purpose for a front-end coder is to **generate dynamic HTML and CSS**, you will be using algorithms to do so (the need to understand that for better react.js learning curve)
- All ways of looping are important, including the `for` loop because its the only one with total freedom and we not only loop arrays, we also loop for other reasons.
- Map vs Foreach: In react we will map all the time because it creates a new array and that is really important.
- Functions goal is: Receive an input and return and output. The execution stops after returning.
- What is `myArray.find` and `myArray.filter`. In React we will use them all the time.

## `2 hours` Last Repl.it/Project Intensive before The DOM!!

☢ 😰 🤯 ️Students are overwhelmed!

This is the most delicate part of the course, there is a **lot of risk on students droping**. Please make sure all of them do lots of replits today.
Do not teach new concepts!

💡 Tell students that today the MUST ask questions after 5 min of being stuck, They cannot try on their own for 30 minutes before asking, not today.
They will have planty of challenges to keep learning on their own tomorrow.

## `45 min` before the class finished, do the student exernal profile with them:
    - Breafly explain open source and why its important, examples of great software build like that.
    - Explain that developers like to collaborate in open source and why its important for them.
    - Pull Request are the best mechanism for collaboration because you don't need permission to push.
    - Students are required to do a real collaboration to a real open source project by the end of the class to an open source project.
    - Talk about the importance of having green dots on your github activity graph.
    - Explain YML breafly.
    - Help them do they YML file and push a draft of their profile (don't worry about content, just structure).
    - Once they do their PR they can see their live profile because we are [automatically merging](https://mergify.io/) and deploying.
    - If the automatic merge does not occur, its probably because their YML has syntax problem, you can review the travis execution log on the pull request details.

Note: They students don't have to worry about the content, today its just about the YML and making it work and show up on the [student list](http://sep.4geeksacademy.co/students/).

days.extended_instructions:
# Day 10 -  The DOM

Before the class, teacher assistants can sti with students and responde eny coding questions.

## `30 min` Introduction about the DOM

No we are goign to be using Javascript to create or change HTML code: The DOM.

- Once the browser recieves the server response it starts building The DOM until `window.onload` gets triggered.
- The DOM is a LIVE hierarchy that represents the HTML document.
- The DOM its not the same as the source code, the source code will be the first version of the DOM ants its quickly overriten by the LIVE changes.
- Draw a DOM example on the whiteboard vs a its corresponding HTML code.
- Show on the browser the google inspector with the DOM opened (the elements tab).
- Show how it changes live based on the user/system activity clicks/mouseover/etc.
- The `querySelector` and `querySelectorAll` will be our main way to use The DOM, the other methods are deprecated: getElementById, byTagName, etc.
- Once you select DOM element and store it on a variable you can change any of its properties: Styles, Classes, Values, etc. ANY PROPERTY!
- Code on the google inspector console a small 2 line script showing a querySelector and changing a style:

```js  
const anyDOMElement = document.querySelector(‘.anyClass’);
//changing a background
anyDOMElement.style.backgroundColor = ‘black’;
//adding a class
anyDOMElement.addClass('d-none');
anyDOMElement.removeClass('d-none');
// inner html
anyDOMElement.innerHTML = "html string that will be included inside the selector"
```

## `10 min` Reinforce what is webpack and npm

Just a brief reminder about bundling, `npm install`, `npm run build`, etc.

## `2:20min ` Start the DOM exercises

Each student rotates the screan, one at a time.

days.extended_instructions:
# `20min` Unit testing

What is a unit test and why do we need it? Explan a simple function like the `sum` function that sums two numbers and how to test it:


```js

function sum(a,b){
     // leave the function without implementation
}

```

What should this function return? a+b

If I pass `5` and `7` to this function, what should the function return? `12`

Unit tests are HARD CODED tests with very specific inputs to function and very specific expectations about the result of those functions.

## How can you assert?

The word "assert" is used in many programming languages testing frameworks, asserting basically means comparing.

We are going to be learning in Javascript and Jest, instead of `assert` you have to say `expect`.

Depending on the framework the syntax varies, but in javascript we assert with Jest like this:
```js
expect(something).toBe(somehitngElse)
```

For example: 
```js
test("If 5 and.7 are passed, then the function must return 12", function(){
    const sum  = require('./sum.js');
    const total = sum(5,7);
    expect(total).toBe(12);
});
```

You can find all the [jest expect functions here](https://jestjs.io/docs/en/expect.html).

## Testing for failure instead of success

1. Try testing your functions for weird scenarios
2. Try to break your functions with the wrong parameters.
3. Think about all the possible scenarios.

There is an interactive project available that will explain a lot to the students, start the project with them and let them finish it on their own.

days.extended_instructions:
# Introduction to React.js ## `5 min` Take any theorical questions about DOM/Javascript ## `30 min` Beginnin of todays new topic Today we will be covering the beginning of creating our first React.js Applications! This topic will be broken up in a few lessons with the overview being today and more detail over the coming days. PLEASE DON’T MISS CLASS and make sure to go to catch up and your own time and saturdays. ### Export -> Import variables among your files Thanks to webpack we can split our code in many files now. All we have to do is expecify what variables we want to share with other files using the `export` sentence. On the other file we can `import` the variable like this: ```js //on file2.js we can declare a function and store it on a variable export let sum = (a,b) => ( return a + b; ); //on file1.js we can import that function and use it like this: import { sum } from 'path/to/file2.js'; console.log(sum(2,7)); ``` ### React JS Introduction A front end javascript library that is used to create advanced HTML/CSS/JS projects. It’s highly in demand in the job market right now and growing. #### Why React? - No more DOM. React handles all of that. You will create your own components and tell react what component to render and when; react handles all interaction with DOM on the front end. - Now its all about component based, its a lot easier to re-use your code int he future. - It’s much faster than traditional javascript. Instead of re-rendering the whole page when a single change occurs, React renders individual items that change. #### You can create your own tags - Before, you learned that HTML Tags are set functions that the browser knows how to interpret. - Now in React, You can create your own tags by creating usable components. - Just create a function that returns HTML and that will become its own tag. - JSX its like HTML+JS you have to get use to it. - You have to use braces in the middle of your HTML to include dynamic JS. ```jsx const Alert = function(props){ return (
{props.children}
); } ReactDOM.render(
{props.children}
) ``` - You have to use [proptypes](https://reactjs.org/docs/typechecking-with-proptypes.html) (best practice). ```js Alert.propTypes = { children: PropTypes.node, // any other property... }; ``` ## `1:25 min` Do the React Exercises with the students The transition to react its hard for the students, that is why we will be doing the react exercises with them. ## `60 min before class ends` Start the class project (Landing Page) - This project will be do in groups of two. - Every team must share the same git repository. - Take some time to read the instructions with the students and have them setup they boilerplate and repository. - Each group will strategize privatly how to approach the exercise.

# Creating Components with States

## `10 min` Take any questions publicly

Remind everyone that doing the exercises about Javascript is extremely important, the only way to become better is practicing, not reading or watching videos.

## `10 min` Review React.js (yes, again)

- React is about components (component names MUST be named in `PascalCase` notation)
- You build components by creating functions (the only function in the worls of JS that MUST start in capital letters)
- Functions must return HTML.
- Those functions can receive information in the form of Properties `<Tag property={value}>`
- Now its className intead of class.
- Everything starts on ReactDOM.render()
- JSX is great because you can mix HTML with JS using braces/curly brackets.

## `20min` Go over the component `useState` hook again

- Properties are defined **ouside** of the component.
- The State is defined **inside** of the component.
- The state is needed when information inside the component will **change over time**.
- You can have as many states as you want.
- Talk about controlled inputs with an example.


## `2:25 min` Start the todolist with the students

Any other project the student may have until this day (like the Traffic Light) is supposed to be done on their own time.

- You can help them a lot on this exercise, but always do it on the whiteboard.
- Help them do the strategy first and later help them complete the exercise.
- This exercise is challenging for the majority of the students, but you will be able to manage if you continue helping them individually.

days.extended_instructions:
# React Router ## Time for some motivation! It is probable that students don't understand things entirely. The probably feel overwhelmed. Good encouragement ideas: - Today is the last class we are introducing new concepts for the front end. - This is everything your need to succeed as a developer for the next 5 years. - The next time you will have to study so much, you will do it with a great sallary!! ## `5 min` Take any questions about fetch.js or any other theorical concept. ## `10 min` Review React.js and Fetch - React is about components (component names MUST be written in caps) - You build components by creating functions or classes (both MUST start in capital letters) - Review how to create a class vs functional component - The component objective is to create HTML. - You can pass props to compoentns `` - You can persist those variables to the DOM using `this.setState` - API Calls (fetch) should be done on `componentDidMount` - Review how to code a fetch ```js fetch('url/to/fetch', additionalSettings) .then(resp => { console.log(resp.ok); // will be tru if the response is successfull console.log(resp.status); // the status code = 200 or code = 400 etc. console.log(resp.text()); // will try return the exact result as string return resp.json(); // (returns promise) will try to parse the result as json as return a promise that you can .then for results }) .then(data => { //here is were your code should start after the fetch finishes console.log(data); //this will print on the console the exact object received from the server }) .catch(error => { //error handling console.log(error); }) ``` # `20 min` Introduce React Router - Most applications have multiple views, or urls. - You don't want the server to take care of "routing", all traffic must be redirected to index.html - The fronn't end will take care of routing the URL path with a particular View (a react component) - Views are react components that you don't typically re-use, like: contact-us, about-us, home, dashboard, etc. - React Router is the most popular library to "route" in React. ## How to route - You need to create a parent component that will be instanciated first and take care of routing. - That component must use `` and several ``'s inside like this: ```jsx ``` Note: We also need a `` because we only one to display one route at time. ### Passing arguments between views using the querystring - HTTP has something call a `queryString` - QueryStrings are a way to pass more information to a URL like this: [google.com/?q=what is react router](google.com/?q=what%20is%20react%20router) As you can see there is a question mark `?` at the end of the URL and then there is a variable `q` equal to `what is react router`. Basically you can tell google.com that you want to query for "what is react router" thru the querystring. The query string always starts with a question mark and then you add unlimited variables and values separated by amperson `&`, for example: `https://www.google.com/search?q=what+is+react+router&start=20` In this case we are passing two variables: `q` and `start`, we are telling google.com that we want to search for "what is react router" and we want to display from the result number 20 instead of 1, we are skipping the first 20 results. #### Retreiving the querystring You can access the querystring from any react component like this: ```jsx const MyComponent = () => { const urlParams = new URLSearchParams(window.location.search); const q = urlParams.get('q'); const start = urlParams.get('start'); return

You want to query in google {q} starting from result {start}

} ``` ### Passing arguments to views using params Aside from the queryString there is another tool to pass information to views in react router, The Params. ```jsx ``` We have two views in this example: `/planets` and `/single_planet/:planet_name`, the first one is going to render a list with all the planets in the solar system, the second one is going to display information about just ONE specific planet. At the end of the `/single_planet/:planet_name` URL you can see there is a color `:` like this: `:planet_name`, this means that `planet_name` will become a variable that will be replaced later with a value, for example: ```txt /single_planet/earth /single_planet/mars /single_planet/neptune /single_planet/jupiter /single_planet/mercury ``` The last part of that URL can vary with different planet_name's, and we can retrieve that information from the component view like this: ```jsx import { useParams } from "react-router"; const SinglePlanet = () => { const { planet_name } = useParams(); return

You are displaying currently the planet {planetName}

} ``` ## `2 hr` Project Time! React the instructions for the starwars blog and strategize with the students: - How many views are needed? - What components you should create? - What are the actions that will be coded? - Today we don't care about the store or actions, lets focus on building the HTML views and the URL paths using react router.

days.extended_instructions:
# Data Modeling whith UML

## `5 min` Take 5 minutes to explain the difference between data-structures and data-models

You can think about data-structures like he RAM Memory repersentation of data-models, for example:

- Data structures are stuff like: Arrays, Trees, Queues (FIFO, FILO), Classes, etc.
- Data models are ways of structuring the database data.

The data-structure of your Reac.tjs projects will: The Store (RAM Memory).
But the data-model is only represented on the backend database.

## `20 min` Today it is about: Data Modeling

[This video](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UI6lqHOVHic&list=PLUoebdZqEHTxNC7hWPPwLsBmWI0KEhZOd) shows how to create a UML diagram, make students watch the video.
Explain the basics of UML with a simple Car dealer example: Vehicle, Client, Purchase.

- What are the possible data-types in a car dealer? Number, Boolean, String, etc.
- What properties can a Vehicle, Client or Purchase have?
- What are tthe relationships between the models (one-to-one, one-to-many, many-to-many)?
    - How many Vehicles a Client can have?
    - How many y Purchases a Client can do?
    - How many Vehicles can a Purchase contain?

## `2:30` Data-Modeling projects

Help students model the StarWars Blog using SQLAlchemy model diagram generator. Read the project instructions with them.

days.extended_instructions:
## Building an API with Flask

## `10min` Intro to backend API's

- Go over HTTP, request vs response.
- Open postman and review with students how to create requests with postman:
     1. How to choose your method GET, PUT, POST, DELETE
     2. How to set the URL
    3. How to set the content-type JSON
    4. where to look for the response
- Postman will be our main way to test our API until we have a front-end.
- The two most important API frameworks in Python are Django and Flask.
- Flask is increasing in popularity because is meant for microservices and that it's very lightweight.

### What is a server?

- A server is just a script that waits for requests, it never ends.
- When a server receives a request it maps the request with a function that we call the "request handler".
- Basically building an API is mapping a bunch of endpoints with functions. One endpoint ==> One function

```py
@app.route('/')
def hello_world():
    return 'Hello, World!'
```

Explain the rest of the process on building an API:  
https://content.breatheco.de/en/lesson/building-apis-with-python-flask

## `1hr` Follow the Interactive Flask API Tutorial

Have the class work on following the API tutorial with Flask (todo list).

## `1:30min` Start the StarWars with the class

- The academy is providing documentation for the Flask Boilerplate here: [start.4geeksacademy.com](https://start.4geeksacademy.com)
- Explain the backend boilerplate before starting the project
- The models.py (based on the database diagram)
- Where to add your endpoints
- How to communicate between Python and your database using SQLAlchemy:
   - How to query information.
   - How to add, delete and update new records.
- Build the first endpoint with the class
- How to test your endpoints with postman

The class must continue working on the API until next day (homework)

days.description:
Almost every application in the world has an authentication system, usually, you choose a username and password and those become your "credentials", you use them every time you want to identify yourself.
Tody we learn how to implement an authentication system using Tokens and JWT, one of the most modern standards for token based API Authentication.
key-concepts: The Auth Token travels on the headers (usually)
API's have private and public endpoints
Every request to a private method must contain the Authorization Header
Types of Authentication (JWT, Bearer, Basic, etc.)
How to send authenticated request in postman
days.teacher_instructions: Explain how authentication works, what is a hash, and how HTTP has no persistent session and we need to generate tokens to simulate the concept of a session, show the documentation of the JWT Extended and help students implement it on their StarWars blog to save favorites on their user account.
days.extended_instructions:
## Authentication

- Start with explaning how HTTP works: request vs response
- We have done request anonymously during the entire course, its time to include authentication in our requests.
- Every request must be "signed" to be able to execute.
- There are many ways to sign requests, usually you do it by appending a unique number (hash/token) that only the authenticated user should know.
- Usually authentication information travels on the header of the request.
- If authentication is invalid the server must returns status code 401 (invalid auth) or 403 (missing auth info).
- What is a token? A unique number that represents the "session".
- How big is the token? Enough to be unique for everyone else.

## Go over the lessons with the student

Take some time to scroll through the lessons and review each of the concepts.

## Use postman to demonstrate an authentication:

  - Start with login (wrong and success credentials)
  - Append the header token to the request.
  - What is the response code we are getting?
  - What happens if I add the wrong headers or token? What status code?

## Documentation for JWT Extended

- Show students the documentation for the [JWT Extended package](https://flask-jwt-extended.readthedocs.io/en/stable/basic_usage/).
- Help students understand how to read a documentation.
  - What to look first? The quickstart?
  - How many weekly downloads the package has?
  - How actively maintained it is?
  - Are there a lot of pending issues?
  - Has anyone else tried the package?
- Write on the board the 4 steps to implement it: 

## Allow students to implement the login and protected routs on the API

Ask students to follow the documentation steps on their own and ask for questions.

## Front-end:

- Implementing the fetch function to post `/token` and get a new token.
- Storing the token on the localStorage
- Appending the token to the fetch headers on every private request 

## The Startwars API should have authentication for next class

# Data-Structures and Family Tree

Today's objective is to start introducing students with the concept of data-structures:

- These are [the available python data-structures](https://github.com/breatheco-de/content/blob/master/src/assets/images/data-structures-python.png?raw=true).
- Mainly divided in primitive and non-primitive.
- We already know all primitives and some of the non-primitives.
- Today we focus on the Tree.

## About Tree's (data-structure)

- Tree are not sequential data-structures like the arrays or lists.
- Trees only have connections between its nodes (items) thru parent->chid links.
- Trees are useful to represent things with hierarchies like the computer file structure, or organizational charts or families.

## Work with the students on the project

We are doing another API to continue practicing Flask but without a database model, only ram memory.
Use dictonaries and try representing a Tree structure (you cannot have all the family members in one array, you must use parent->child connectors.

days.extended_instructions:
# Time To Start the Final Project

We are going to use github for SCRUM project management, that way students get more green points on the activity graph and they get more familiar with github.

## `10min` Creating user stories

This video is great about user stories: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LGeDZmrWwsw
This is the lesson: http://content.breatheco.de/lesson/user-stories-examples

- Don't undermine stories: 70% of the projects fail because the requirements are not clear enough.
- User stories have to be worded on the user point of view.
- They need to have a clear **Acceptance Criteria**.
- You application roles & capabilities, make sure the stories involve them: `as a students I would like to sort my lessons by difficulty`
- SPRINT: Its a coding iteration (Every week maybe?) from start to finish: Write the stories -> Prioritize -> Code -> Test -> Deliver.
- Velocity: How many points are being delivered per sprint.
- SCRUM Meeting: Its when the team strategizes and plans a new sprint: decides what features are going to be included into the sprint.
- Standup Meeting: Every day, the group gathers for 10 minutes and answers 2 questions:
    1. Are you stuck?
    2. What do you need from me?

## `10min` Using Github for Agile: Issues and Projects

- There are plenty of agile methodologies but we decided to use Kanban as it is one of the most popular ones.
- Explain github issues and how you can create one issue for eavery feature/bug/problem/etc.
- Github issues can connect to github projects automatically.
- Create a github project with the students: What is a Kanban board and how does it work: 4 Columns (Backlog, Selected for Development, In Progress, Done).
- How to use Github's kanban automated board: Issues will automatically opened and closed.

## `20min` Students must pick their final project

- Have a brainstorming on the project, here are some examples:
    1. Doing an SMS based todo list application.
    2. Doing a real-time polling platform like pollanywhere: https://www.polleverywhere.com/
    3. Doing a Markdown editor to take notes and save them in the cloud.
    4. Doing a detting platform where games can bet on anyone playing a video game.
    5. Online store.
- Once you ahve teams and ideas ready the teams must gather up and one of each team must create their repository.
- Each team must start adding github issues with their user stories.

## `2:20min` Build project stories

Students must work in group with their teams to finish the first batch of user stories and wireframes and publish them into github.

days.extended_instructions:
# Coach students on their development

It is the first time students code a big project, they are probably making lots of mistakes, they have probably ugly designs or maybe they don;t event know what they are doing.

## Sit with each team separately and help them with the following:

#### Were to look for mistakes

- The overcomplicate things.
- They spend too much time on non-important stuff.
- They use libraries that don't work.
- They want to add so many features to their projects that they forget its going to be impossible to finish.

#### Were to look for bad UX/UI designs:

- Use a maximum of 3 colors on your projects.
- Use bootstrap components all the way: Reactstrap or Materialize is a great recomendation.
- Someone form the team should focus on little details a lot, like a full time job.

### Make sure they are following SCRUM

- Are they using github project?
- Are they moving the ard in the Kanban board?
